page.title: 12Life of an Eckington person.
page.content: Mrs. Gill told us that there weren't many girls in Eckington between 1945 and 1955. Everyone was glad when a baby girl was born. The main jobs in 1950 were filling trucks with coal, working on the land and working on the railways. The roads weren't busy, but train travel was cheap so it was very busy. The shops in Eckington were The Corner shop, Post Office and The Well. The Bell, Crown and Anchor were, and still are, the pubs. The hot water was put in in 1955. The villagers kept cats, pigs and chickens. The cats stopped the rats and mice getting to the corn, which was fed to the other animals. Sometimes the floods in Eckington came right up to Boon street, and "Once the flood was about 2ft deep outside my house" Mrs. Gill said. Villagers made lots of Home-made wines like plum and damson wine.
